insider_note: 100% Chardonnay from La Tuilerie vineyard in Vandières; natural methods with indigenous yeasts, oak aging; shows stone fruits, citrus, saline minerality, and oxidative almond notes; extra brut with low dosage; benefits from 5+ years aging post-disgorgement.

insider_note: Dauvissat La Forest is one of the benchmark Premier Cru Chablis: intensely mineral and saline with searing, citrus-driven acidity in youth and a rounder, honeyed, more complex texture as it ages, making it superb for high-end seafood and capable of long cellaring.[1][2][4][6]

Iconic entry-level Chardonnay from declassified Auxey-Duresses and Puligny-Montrachet parcels, aged in neutral oak; firm, rich, and age-worthy with subtle tannins and harmonious fruit concentration[1][3]
Iconic biodynamic Chardonnay from declassified Auxey-Duresses and Puligny-Montrachet parcels; firm, rich, and age-worthy with subtle tannins unusual for whites.

pairing_tags: buttery chicken,turkey,roast poultry,creamy pasta,rich seafood,shellfish,soft cheeses
insider_note: For an entry-level Bourgogne Blanc this drinks surprisingly rich and concentrated, with medium to medium-plus body, moderate acidity, and a plush almost slightly oily texture; the style leans more toward stone and tropical fruit with subtle oak than racy citrus, so treat it more like a food wine for richer dishes than a super-crisp aperitif.

wine_name: "la corvée de bully" hautes-côtes de beaune pinot blanc
insider_note: Delightful white blend of 80% Chardonnay and 20% Pinot Blanc (or Aligoté in some cuvées) from Hautes-Côtes de Beaune; pure vivid nose of white orchard fruits, grass, anise; intense palate with lovely depth, power, and salinity. Scores 90-91 pts, classical style with emotion[1][2][6].

wine_name: "la corvée de bully" hautes-côtes de beaune
pairing_tags: oysters, shellfish, ceviche, goat cheese, sushi, vegetable tempura, grilled white fish, fresh salads
insider_note: Faure’s La Corvée de Bully is a tension-driven Hautes-Côtes white (mainly Chardonnay with some Pinot Blanc/Aligoté depending on cuvée) showing vivid orchard fruit, pronounced saline zest and chiselled freshness; treat it more like top Chablis than a generic Bourgogne and serve quite cool in a Burgundy white stem to highlight its energy.

Chassagne-Montrachet 1er Cru whites like Clos Saint Jean offer exotic fruit and hazelnut aromas with minerality from limestone-clay soils; expect elegant freshness and aging potential up to 15 years from oak-aged Chardonnay.

insider_note: Colonia is a single-vineyard 100% Sangiovese aged over 30 months in new French barrique, giving a powerful yet refined structure with pronounced acidity and tannin, mineral-iron notes, dark cherry and wild berries; it benefits greatly from long decanting or 8–15 years of cellar time.[1][2][3][9]

Generous Monte Bello, harmonious depth.

insider_note: Classic white Chassagne-Montrachet from Benoît Moreau is typically a rich yet tightly structured Chardonnay: ripe stone-fruit and citrus layered over flinty minerality, with firm but balanced acidity and a rounded, creamy mid-palate. Expect it to show well now with aeration but gain honeyed, hazelnut nuance and more depth over 5–8 years, especially in stronger vintages.

pairing_tags: roast chicken, duck breast, pork loin, mushroom dishes, mild washed-rind cheeses
insider_note: High-altitude, calcareous Maranges 1er Cru fruit gives this Pinot a bright, mineral-driven profile with lifted red fruit and moderate, silky tannins—treat it like a mini–Côte de Beaune insider pick rather than a rustic southern outlier.

pairing_tags: roast_chicken, pork_tenderloin, charcuterie, mushroom_dishes, grilled_salmon, soft_cheeses
insider_note: Light, fully-destemmed Pinot Noir grown on granitic rock, showing a strong stony minerality, smoky granite notes and an airy, delicate frame; best slightly cool and with food rather than as a standalone sipper.

wine_name: "la vie est belle" pernand-vergelesses 1er cru pinot blanc
insider_note: Natural white from 100% Pinot Blanc, vinified like a red without sulfites; expect unique apple, yeast, and mineral freshness from biodynamic Pernand-Vergelesses 1er Cru.

pairing_tags: roast chicken, duck, veal, pork loin, mushroom dishes, mild game, soft cheeses
insider_note: Classic Côte de Beaune Pinot Noir: bright red cherry and raspberry with forest floor and floral nuances, medium body, refined tannins, and lively acidity that make it especially versatile at the table and capable of graceful mid-term aging.

wine_name: "la pièce sous le bois" meursault-blagny 1er cru

pairing_tags: charcuterie, roast chicken, pork loin, mild washed-rind cheese, lentil stew
insider_note: Juicy, low-extraction Loire red from Anjou with a natural-leaning touch; chill slightly and drink young for bright red fruit, florals, and easy bistro-style versatility.

pairing_tags: charcuterie, roast chicken, pork loin, goat cheese, veggie roast, bistro fare
insider_note: Light, Loire-natural in style: bright, crunchy red fruits, low extract and very drinkable—treat it more like a serious bistro wine than a structured cellar red.

pairing_tags: shellfish, oysters, lobster, scallops, white fish, roast chicken, veal, creamy sauces, goat cheese, aged chèvre, gruyère, vegetable terrine
insider_note: Top Brézé Chenin Blanc from limestone soils: high-strung acidity, saline precision and layered texture make this closer in spirit to fine white Burgundy than to typical Loire Chenin; decanting and serving cool-but-not-cold (around 11–12°C) lets the citrus, stone fruit and subtle honeyed notes unfold and reveals serious ageing potential.

Clos de la Rue from Brézé yields a precise, crystal-sharp Chenin Blanc with intense freshness, salinity, and tension from calcareous sand and limestone soils; light-bodied yet textural with great aging potential, vinified in foudres and barrels on fine lees.

pairing_tags: duck,roast chicken,veal,mushroom dishes,game bird,grilled salmon,hard cheese
insider_note: Clos des Forêts is a monopole 1er cru from biodynamically farmed old vines in the southern Nuits-Saint-Georges; recent vintages under Géraldine Godot show a more refined, floral style than the appellation’s rustic reputation, with vibrant red fruit, spice and a long, saline finish.

Clos des Forêts is a rare 1er Cru monopole of Domaine de l'Arlot in Nuits-Saint-Georges, known for its structured yet elegant Pinot Noir with dark fruit, spice, and earthy depth; muscular and age-worthy like top NSG Premiers.

Top-tier single-vineyard Sangiovese from Panzano’s Conca d’Oro, Vigna del Sorbo combines high, citrusy acidity with ripe yet grippy tannins and a mid-to-full body; decant generously in its first 10–15 years to let the dark cherry, tobacco, and savory herbal notes unfurl, and don’t be afraid to cellar the best vintages for two decades or more for maximum complexity.[1][2][3][5][8]

insider_note: High-altitude, biodynamically farmed Sangiovese with long aging in large botti gives Vigneti del Versante a rare mix of vibrant acidity, fine but assertive tannins, and aromatic lift (citrus, herbs, red fruits), so decant generously and serve slightly cooler than typical Brunello (~16–17°C) to emphasize its precision over sheer power.

insider_note: Chardonnay Blanc de Blancs from chalky Coteaux Sud d'Epernay terroir, vinified in oak barrels, delivering vibrant minerality, citrus, and white fruit notes with fine energy.

pairing_tags: roast chicken, grilled fish, creamy sauces
insider_note: Biodynamically farmed Chardonnay from Burgundy, offering vibrant freshness, mineral purity, and elegant balance across vintages like 2020-2023; full-bodied yet racy with citrus, orchard fruit, and stony finish[1][2][3][4][5][8].

pairing_tags: braised beef, bistecca alla fiorentina, roasted meats
insider_note: Pure Sangiovese from Felsina's Berardenga estate; consistently scores 90-94 points across vintages for fine-grained, firm tannins, vibrant acidity, and notes of cherry, herbs, spice; ages well in large Slavonian oak, best with 3-10 years cellaring.

pairing_tags: duck, lamb, roast chicken, mushroom dishes, hard cheese, game birds
insider_note: Traditional, ageworthy Pommard from Ampeau tends to show firm acidity and a solid, sometimes hard tannic backbone in youth, evolving into a savory, earthy profile with red fruits and noticeable structure; decant well and pair with richer, protein-heavy, earthy dishes for best balance.

Terroir-driven Blanc de Blancs from old vines in Cramant and Chouilly; immense tension from minerality and tiny bubbles, with smoky complexity, oak influence, and low 4g/L dosage; agile and athletic feel[1].

pairing_tags: lobster, scallops, turbot, roast chicken, morel cream sauce, Comté, aged goat cheese
insider_note: Top-end Chassagne 1er Cru from Morgeot’s Tête de Clos is typically one of the domaine’s more powerful, structured whites: generous oak, ripe stone fruit and hazelnut over a mineral, saline core, with enough acidity to reward 8–12 years of cellaring in good vintages.
Ouillé Savagnin from Sous-Roche parcel; ultra-fresh with stony minerality, summer fruit, and subtle caramelization notes despite topped-up style.

Mountain-grown Rioja from high, stony slopes: Remelluri under Telmo Rodríguez is fresher and more terroir-driven than most reservas, with bright acidity, fine-grained tannins and a supple, satiny texture that lets red fruit, herbs and subtle oak shine—think serious but not heavy, built to age yet very drinkable now with hearty, savory dishes.

pairing_tags: lamb, grilled meats, game, hard cheeses, mushroom dishes, rioja-classic
insider_note: Remelluri under Telmo Rodríguez is a high-altitude, estate-grown Rioja with notable freshness, fine-grained tannins, and a more terroir-driven, less oaky profile than many traditional Reservas—think structured yet elegant, ideal for cellaring or decanting to reveal its wild red fruit, herbal and mineral nuances.[1][2][3]

Dom Gris is a delicate, low-alcohol Hokkaido Pinot Gris made with wild yeasts and minimal inputs, showing clean stone fruit and spice with medium, refreshing acidity rather than Alsatian-style richness; treat it like a serious, natural-leaning food wine and serve just below fridge-cold to highlight its precision.
Gevrey-Chambertin; power, game, structure.

Nuits-Saint-Georges 1er Cru Les Damodes from Chantêrêves offers a robust yet refined Pinot Noir profile with dark fruit, spice, and earthy notes, structured for aging with vibrant acidity balancing firm tannins.

Les Damodes sits on the Vosne side of Nuits-Saint-Georges, so Chanterêves’ style here is more floral and lifted than brawny NSG; expect red fruit, spice, fine-grained tannins and vibrant acidity, and don’t serve it too warm (15–16°C shows the perfume best).
Grand Cru power; red fruit and muscle.

insider_note: Jean-Marc Pillot’s Chassagne-Montrachet 1er Cru Les Vergers typically shows the climat’s hallmark high acidity, minerality and white-flower/citrus profile, with a broad but precise palate; it is best with 5–10 years of bottle age, when the flinty edge, hazelnut and subtle buttery notes knit into a very fine, tension-driven texture.

pairing_tags: poultry, roast chicken, turkey, creamy sauces, shellfish, lobster, scallops, rich fish, mushroom dishes
insider_note: Les Vergers from Jean-Marc Pillot is typically one of the more mineral and high-tension Chassagne 1er Crus: expect incisive acidity, flinty drive and white-flower citrus aromatics wrapped in a broad but precise mid-palate, making it ideal to serve slightly cooler than usual for Chardonnay to emphasize its cut and salinity.
2014 cut; red-fruited, tensile, best with food and air.
Balanced, vibrant; prime drinking window now.
2020 wet year, balanced freshness.

pairing_tags: duck, lamb, roast chicken, mushroom dishes, hard cheeses
insider_note: Confuron-Cotetidot’s Vignes Rondes in Nuits-St.-Georges will typically show a robust, dark-fruited, and earthy Pinot Noir profile with good acidity and firm but polished tannins, in line with the appellation’s muscular yet velvety style; it benefits from several years of cellaring to soften its structure and reveal more complex game, truffle, and spice notes.
Pure, tense Extra Brut Blanc de Blancs from old Chardonnay vines in Avize and Cramant Grand Crus, showcasing saline chalk minerality and vibrant citrus purity.
100% Chardonnay Grand Cru d'Avize et Cramant, tension minérale saisissante, énergie saline, finale crayeuse persistante.

One of the reference grower Champagnes for chalky, saline precision in Blanc de Blancs; serve a touch warmer than usual (around 10–11°C) to let the chalk and citrus complexity show over the sheer tension.

pairing_tags: oysters, shellfish, meaty fish, oily fish, goat cheese, lemon-based dishes
insider_note: Biodynamic, partially skin-macerated Aligoté from deep marl and clay in Volnay; very high, tense acidity, pronounced salinity and chalky extract, showing green-citrus and white-fruit notes—treat it like a serious, mineral Chablis for pairings and serving (cool, not icy).

wine_name: "clos de la coulèe de serrant" savennières
pairing_tags: roasted poultry, foie gras, aged cheeses
insider_note: Nicolas Joly's biodynamic Clos de la Coulée de Serrant is one of the world's top dry Chenin Blancs, austere and tight in youth with explosive apricot-quince aromas, firm acidity, subtle grainy tannins, and exceptional aging potential up to decades; occasionally includes noble rot for added complexity.

insider_note: Young Bourgogne Pinot Noir from Guilbert-Gillet’s Les Perrières shows bright red cherry and berry fruit with earthy and mineral notes, juicy freshness, and moderate but present tannins; it benefits from a short cellaring or a good splash in a decanter to smooth the texture.[2][3][5][7][8]

insider_note: Roumier’s Bourgogne rouge is essentially a declassified Chambolle-influenced Pinot: expect lifted red fruit, floral notes and refined structure; serve slightly cool (15–16°C) to emphasize its finesse over power.

wine_name: extra brut ∙ l'échappée belle ∙ blanc de blancs
pairing_tags: apéritif, fruits de mer, plats légers
insider_note: Cuvée signature Blanc de Blancs (Chardonnay) d'Étienne Calsac à Avize, extra brut à l'attaque soyeuse et gourmande avec notes minérales, vinifié minimaliste en inox et fûts pour texture crémeuse et fraîcheur vibrante[1][2][3].
2011 charm; midweight, fragrant, for Burgundy traditionalists.
Consider electric NV Champagne or cold, lean vodka pairing.
Maximal protein: reach for solar, ripe 2015 classics.
Prestige Rosé: vibrant berries, fine mousse, gastronomic style.
Young 2023, vibrant Chassagne energy.
Mature Barbera blend, soft evolution.
Anniversary icon, tannic beast.
2021 Lavières: limestone‑driven Savigny; bright, crunchy red fruits and spice.

pairing_tags: butter-poached shellfish, white fish with beurre blanc, roast chicken, seared scallops, lobster, richer cream-sauce pasta, comté-style cheeses
insider_note: Fontaine-Gagnard’s Chassagne 1er Cru Vergers is typically a brisk, citrus-and-stone driven white Burgundy with incisive, almost Puligny-like acidity but a slightly rounder, more Chassagne-style mid-palate; expect tension over power, restrained oak, and best drinking from ~5–12 years from vintage.

pairing_tags: grilled meats, aged cheeses, hearty stews
insider_note: Leonetti's pioneering Walla Walla estate style delivers bold power with finesse; this Aglianico from Serra Perdace Vineyard likely showcases gorgeously managed tannins and purity true to the winery's benchmark reputation.[1][2]

A benchmark Schioppettino from its historic home in Cialla: expect vivid red and dark berries, prominent white pepper and balsamic notes, with lively acidity and velvety tannins that make it both food-friendly and capable of long ageing.

pairing_tags: grilled red meat, roasted dishes, aged cheeses
insider_note: Iconic Super Tuscan blend of Sangiovese (25-45%) and Merlot (55-75%) from Montalcino, aged 24 months in oak; delivers elegant structure with ripe fruit, spice, and long mineral finish[1][2][3][6][9]

wine_name: pinot grigio ∙ fuoripista ∙ vigneti delle dolomiti
pairing_tags: seafood, shellfish, grilled fish, aromatic Asian dishes, roast poultry, soft cheeses, alpine cheeses, charcuterie, vegetable antipasti
insider_note: Iconic amphora-fermented orange Pinot Grigio with 8+ months on skins; expect serious structure for the grape, with pronounced but velvety tannins, bright mountain acidity, and a salty mineral edge that lets it behave almost like a light red at the table.

Radikon's natural Merlot from Friuli features skin contact and oak aging, yielding complex, mineral-driven wines with earthy, fruity notes; variable reviews highlight its cult status but sensitivity to storage.
Pure Pinot Noir from a single parcel in Ambonnay Grand Cru, old vines (avg. 42 years), oak barrel vinified without malolactic fermentation for vibrant freshness and structure.

Single-parcel Ambonnay Chardonnay with very low dosage, this Extra Brut Blanc de Blancs from Les Genettes shows ripe stone fruit, chalky minerality, and medium-plus body; it drinks more vinous and gastronomic than aperitif-y, so treat it like a fine white Burgundy with bubbles and give it a large glass and a bit of air.

pairing_tags: raw_bar, fried_food, soft_pungent_cheese, roast_chicken, sushi_sashimi, citrus_seafood
insider_note: Equal parts of all seven permitted Champagne grapes and just 0–1 g/L dosage make this a very high-acid, bone-dry grower Champagne with a chalky Verzy Grand Cru spine; decant or give it plenty of air to let the orchard fruit, citrus zest, herbs, and spice emerge.

pairing_tags: seafood, shellfish, goat cheese, light poultry
insider_note: Top Chablis monopole from biodynamic Chardonnay on Kimmeridgian limestone; tonic, perfumed with green apple and citrus, aged 24 months on lees in oak; exceptional minerality and energy[1][3][6]
Rich, barrel-fermented Chardonnay with mouthwatering freshness, stone fruit, and creamy notes from lees stirring; ages well due to concentration.

Among Huet’s vineyards, Clos du Bourg Moelleux is typically the most powerful and concentrated expression of sweet Vouvray Chenin, combining very high acidity with intense sweetness for decades-long aging potential.[2][4][8]

pairing_tags: shellfish, white_fish, goat_cheese, sushi, tempura, light_poultry, fresh_herbs
insider_note: Classic dry Huet from Le Haut-Lieu: very high, tensile acidity and chalky-mineral grip wrapped in refined, silky fruit (green apple, pear, citrus, sometimes stone fruit). Decant young vintages and serve cool but not cold to soften the edges and let the texture and florality emerge.

Chenin‑driven La Porte Saint Jean whites from Saumur/VdF tend to be racy and mineral, with prominent acidity and a lightly waxy, saline texture; treat it more like top, incisive Loire Chenin than a soft bistro blanc, and pour it alongside briny, simply prepared seafood or young Loire goat cheese to show off its tension.
Elegant Languedoc red led by non-cloned Cabernet Sauvignon (75-80%) with rare varieties; harmonious power, mocha-cassis notes, fine tannins; ages 10+ years on glacial soils.
Iconic Languedoc Cabernet-dominant blend from glacial soils, showing dense tannins, vibrant acidity, and complex fruity-herbal profile; ages exceptionally well[1][2][4]

insider_note: High-energy, terroir-driven grower rosé Champagne: intense red fruit and blood orange with a chalky, saline finish; extra-brut dosage and fine mousse make it more a gastronomic table wine than an aperitif-only bubbly.

Rare biodynamic Chardonnay from Pouilly-Fuissé, aged 2+ years in oak, with powerful white fruit, floral, citrus aromas and noble acidity for aging; only ~300 bottles produced.

Vibrant 2022 Chassagne; mineral freshness.
Les Folies: oak-kissed, orchard-fruited, versatile food Champagne.
Playful NV, red fruit and zesty energy.
Crisp bubbles, versatile aperitif sparkle.
Taurasi Riserva, volcanic intensity.
2021 Loire cool vintage: lean, vibrant acidity.

Classic Volnay 1er Cru Taillepieds from Bitouzet-Prieur is typically red-fruited, floral and mineral, with lifted acidity and fine-grained tannins; it benefits from decanting when young and shows best with 8–15 years of bottle age.

pairing_tags: bistecca alla fiorentina, grilled ribeye, lamb chops, aged pecorino, braised short ribs, venison
insider_note: Grattamacco Bolgheri (especially the Superiore) is a structured yet elegant coastal Tuscan Bordeaux-style blend: full-bodied, with crisp acidity and fine but firm tannins that benefit from a long decant in youth; its Sangiovese component adds lift and savory nuance, making it unusually food-versatile for such a powerful Bolgheri wine.

wine_name: timorasso · colli tortonesi riserva · grand fostó
pairing_tags: seafood, white fish, risotto, aged cheese
insider_note: Complex riserva Timorasso with savory citrus, saline minerality, and honeyed stone fruit; structured and age-worthy white from Colli Tortonesi[1][3][6].

La Riotte is a Premier Cru site in Morey-Saint-Denis known for structured Pinot Noir with bold yet fresh tannins, black fruit, and excellent aging potential; expect unctuous texture and mineral notes[1][2][4].

pairing_tags: roast chicken, duck, mushroom dishes, soft cheeses
insider_note: Simon Bize's Savigny-lès-Beaune exemplifies the appellation's feminine style with fine structure, morello cherry and raspberry notes; seek northern Premier Crus like Marconnets for elegance and fruit purity.

A benchmark natural Frappato from Vittoria: serve slightly chilled (15–16°C) to highlight its bright acidity, crunchy red fruit and sandy, gently grippy tannins—treat it more like a serious cru Beaujolais than a typical full-bodied Sicilian red.

Field blend VDF from Stéphane Bernaudeau in Anjou, echoing floral-spicy Grolleau-driven profiles like nearby Ogereau's L'Enjouée; light reds with peppery nuance and crisp red fruits, ideal for casual sharing.
Elegant sparkling wine with refreshing acidity.

pairing_tags: seafood, white fish, shellfish, roast chicken, white meats, mild cheeses, vegetable antipasti
insider_note: Single‑vineyard Malvasia del Lazio noted for its ability to age slowly; expect high, mouthwatering acidity and a rich but balanced, saline profile with stone fruit, waxy/honeyed and nutty tones that pairs especially well with simply prepared seafood and delicate white meats.[1][3][6][8][9]

pairing_tags: seafood, white_fish, shellfish, roast_chicken, white_meats, creamy_pasta, aged_cheese, antipasti
insider_note: Single-vineyard Malvasia del Lazio built for long aging: expect evolved notes of baked stone fruit, honey, wax and nuts over a vibrant, saline core, so give it air and serve not too cold to let the complexity and subtle grip show.[1][2][3][7][8][9]
Light, youthful Teroldego from sandy alluvial soils in Trentino, biodynamically farmed, aged 8-12 months in clay amphorae for freshness, minerality, and fine dry tannins.
Top Chenin Blanc from 70+ year-old vines on Saint-Georges schist; barrel-aged 2 years, needs several years of bottle age for peak complexity with saline minerality and fruit-driven freshness.

Mark Angeli’s Vieilles Vignes des Blanderies is a powerful, long‑aged dry Chenin from very old vines on schist, showing high tension, salty grip and a faint, stimulating bitterness; give it air or a few years in bottle and treat it more like a serious white Burgundy than a simple Loire Chenin.

Eyrie flagship, site-driven finesse.
Solar Sonoma ripeness; plush, dreamy.

pairing_tags: oysters, sashimi, crudo, tartare, soft goat cheese, tempura, fried chicken
insider_note: Super-low dosage grower Champagne from Pinot Noir: expect laser-cut acidity, salty-mineral precision, and very little fruit sweetness, so serve it with briny or fatty dishes rather than on its own if you’re used to fuller, richer styles.

pairing_tags: scallop risotto, chicken in creamy sauce, goat cheese, roast chicken, butter-laden mashed potatoes
insider_note: Chardonnay from prestigious Burgundy domaine, primarily from declassified Chalumeaux 1er Cru plot; smooth, lively with savory character, fresh fruit and citrus aromas, long finish with toasted almonds; light oak influence for purity.

pairing_tags: game meat, aged cheeses, salami, hearty stews
insider_note: Paolo Bea's Pagliaro is a benchmark Sagrantino from old vines, showcasing dense, earthy depth with porcini, black fruits, and seamless tannin integration after extended aging; decant generously for its powerful structure.

pairing_tags: Tuscan, tomato-based pasta, grilled lamb, roast poultry, aged pecorino, earthy mushroom dishes, charcuterie
insider_note: Classic high-altitude Sangiovese Grosso from Biondi-Santi: vibrant, red-fruited and floral with marked freshness, fine-grained tannins and a savory, mineral finish—think of it as a more agile, early‑drinking baby Brunello that still benefits from decanting and can age 8–10 years.

pairing_tags: seafood, oysters, smoked salmon, sushi, aperitif, grilled fish, white meats
insider_note: From old vines in Cramant and Chouilly Grand Crus, this Extra Brut Blanc de Blancs (dosage 4g/L) delivers athletic tension with crystalline acidity, saline minerality, fine bubbles, and chalky persistence; organic since 2019, aged in concrete eggs and oak.[1][2][3]

pairing_tags: raw_bar, oysters, sashimi, citrus_seafood, minimalist_poultry, goat_cheese, aperitif
insider_note: From a single old-vine Chardonnay parcel in Le Mesnil-sur-Oger (planted 1971), this zero-dosage, no-sulfur Blanc de Blancs is one of Vincey’s most linear and saline cuvées: medium-bodied but intensely mineral, with mouthwatering, high acidity, citrus zest, chalk and oyster-shell notes, and a long, tense finish—serve in a white-wine stem and give it air to unlock the hazelnut and herbal complexity.[1][2][4]
Exceptional purity and vibrancy from biodynamic Chardonnay vineyards near Puligny-Montrachet, offering bright acidity, subtle texture, and aging potential beyond typical Bourgogne Blanc.

pairing_tags: buttery seafood, roast chicken, lobster, scallops, creamy pasta, soft cheeses
insider_note: Classic, high-acid white Burgundy: citrus, white peach and subtle smoke with a long, precise finish—give it air or a few years in bottle to unlock its full texture and complexity.

pairing_tags: buttery seafood, roast chicken, lobster, scallops, richer white fish, veal in cream sauce, mushroom poultry dishes, soft rind cheeses
insider_note: Classic white Burgundy Chardonnay from Chassagne-Montrachet: full-bodied yet finely balanced, with bright acidity, orchard fruit, subtle brioche/vanillin oak, and a long, mineral-inflected finish; shows best slightly cool (not cold) and can benefit from 30–45 minutes in a decanter for young vintages.

pairing_tags: shellfish, roast chicken, turkey, creamy seafood, mild cheeses
insider_note: Classic high-acid, mineral Saint-Aubin 1er Cru Chardonnay from a cult domaine; look for citrus, green apple, subtle butter and nuts with a saline, incisive finish.

wine_name: "chercheurs d'or" vin de paille, jura sud revermont
pairing_tags: foie gras, magret aux épices, aperitif, dark chocolate
insider_note: Rare vin de paille from passerillé grapes dried on straw for months, aged in old oak; perfect balance of acidity and sweetness, natural vinification from Domaine Labet in Jura Sud Revermont.

pairing_tags: shellfish, lobster, scallops, roast chicken, veal, creamy sauces, aged goat cheese, gruyère, mushroom dishes
insider_note: Thibaud Boudignon’s Clos de la Hutte is a benchmark dry Savennières: very high acidity and concentrated old-vine Chenin on schist give a tense, waxy, mineral palate with light phenolic grip; decanting or a few hours open in the glass helps it unfurl, and it can age effortlessly for a decade or more.
Flagship white blending 80% Marsanne with Roussanne; restrained for Northern Rhône with tropical fruit, stoniness, and surprising acidity providing shape to its round, weighty palate[1][3][4].

Merlot-based blend showing plush fruit over solid Friulian structure.

pairing_tags: oysters, shellfish, sashimi, lean fish, crustaceans
insider_note: Bone-dry Brut Nature Champagne from Amaury Beaufort, showcasing pure terroir with floral, white fruit, and mineral notes; creamy saline palate with no added dosage for precise, austere expression.

wine_name: Extra Brut Chetillion de Haut Blanc de Blancs
pairing_tags: oysters, raw shellfish, sashimi, sole meunière, lemon chicken, goat cheese, hard alpine cheeses, caviar, tempura, light citrus desserts
insider_note: High-tension, mineral-driven Blanc de Blancs from Mesnil chalk soils; expect laser-like acidity, saline chalk, and citrus/stone fruit rather than bready richness, so serve in a white-wine glass and don’t over-chill to let the silkier mid-palate and ripe fruit emerge.

pairing_tags: rich seafood, roast chicken, alpine cheese, mushroom dishes, risotto, herb-driven cuisine
insider_note: Timorasso from Montemarzino is one of Roagna’s sleeper bottles: long oak aging and the grape’s natural structure give it a Riesling-like acid line with serious weight and a faintly oily, saline, phenolic grip—decant and serve not too cold to unlock the mint, almond and honeyed citrus complexity.[1][2][3][4][6][7]

pairing_tags: truffle, mushroom, game bird, alpine cheese, charcuterie, polenta, roast pork
insider_note: Etichetta Bianca is a benchmark alpine Nebbiolo: pale garnet, highly perfumed (rose, alpine herbs, red berries), with bright, almost racy acidity and fine but present tannins; decant 1–2 hours and serve just cool of cellar to highlight its mineral, ‘sun and stone’ finesse rather than power.

Montestefano is one of Barbaresco’s most powerful crus, and Serafino Rivella makes it in a very traditional, long-maceration style: expect high acidity, serious tannin, and a tightly wound, old-school profile that needs several hours in a decanter or 10–15 years in bottle to show its full depth.
Structured and balanced red wine profile.
Conterno Barbera 2022, solar body.
Fresh, high-toned mountain Nebbiolo; think crystalline Barolo in miniature.
La Serra precision; cool bright fruit.
2018 ripe: good structure.
Super-classic Barbaresco from Neive's Albesani cru; lifted aromatics, mid-weight structure, fine persistent tannins; needs time to develop, drink 2024-2032.

Organic grower Champagne from 2.5ha in Cumières Premier Cru; 57% Chardonnay, 33% Pinot Noir, 10% Pinot Meunier blend fermented in oak with zero dosage; nervy energy, mineral drive, and layered complexity from old vines.
Quintessential Volnay from old vines in Volnay village; elegant, perfumed, with firm structure for aging; gentle winemaking preserves delicacy using native yeasts and minimal new oak.

pairing_tags: carpaccio de Saint-Jacques, sole meunière, salade de chèvre chaud, sashimi, tempura
insider_note: Franc pied vines on argilo-calcaire soils yield a Chenin Blanc of crystalline precision, high tension, and chalky minerality; vive attack with persistent, salivating finish from biodynamic farming.

pairing_tags: carpaccio de Saint-Jacques, sole meunière, salade de chèvre chaud, sashimi, tempura
insider_note: Vive tension acide, pureté remarquable, minéralité calcaire typique du terroir argilo-calcaire, finale nette et salivante; Chenin Blanc sec de finesse exceptionnelle, à carafer jeune.

pairing_tags: roast venison, ceps, rosemary, red meat, game
insider_note: 50% Syrah and 50% Cabernet Sauvignon blend, organically farmed, whole cluster fermentation, 24 months aging in foudres, very fine and refined tannins with exceptional aging potential of 20-30 years.

2008 Barolo: Mature cherry, soft tannins.
2021 Aux Fourneaux: slightly riper fruit, same fresh spine; very gastronomic.

Classic Taurasi Riserva from Guastaferro will be intensely structured Aglianico: very high tannin and vibrant acidity wrapped in a full, concentrated body, showing dark cherry, plum, tobacco, leather and spicy notes with a long, evolving finish; decant several hours or cellar 10–20+ years for optimal harmony.[1][2][4][6]

pairing_tags: roast chicken, duck, pork loin, charcuterie, mushroom dishes, grilled salmon, soft cheeses
insider_note: High-toned, perfumed Bourgogne Pinot Noir with bright red fruit, marked freshness and very fine, powdery tannins; serve slightly cool (around 15–16°C) to accentuate the tension and aromatics.
Pure Pinot expression, soil-driven purity.
2021 Napa Cab blend: ripe, structured, bold Napa power.
Modern Napa Cab: generous fruit wrapped in serious, dinner-worthy structure.

pairing_tags: bistecca alla fiorentina, grilled lamb, tomato-based pasta, aged pecorino, roasted poultry
insider_note: Classic high-altitude Radda Sangiovese: bright red fruit, lifted acidity, fine but persistent tannins and a medium body that gains depth with a few hours in a decanter; serves as a benchmark for elegant, traditional Tuscan reds.

pairing_tags: oysters, sashimi, white fish, crab, lobster, citrus-driven dishes, soft goat cheese
insider_note: Classic grower Grand Cru Blanc de Blancs: very high acidity, chalky-mineral and citrus-led with fine, persistent mousse; best at the table with delicate seafood rather than as a simple aperitif.

pairing_tags: lobster, scallops, grilled white fish, roast chicken, pork loin, aged goat cheese, Comté, vegetable terrines
insider_note: Top Savennières from Boudignon’s La Vigne Cendrée is a reference-point dry Chenin: laser acidity, dense but saline fruit, and a long, smoky-mineral finish; give it air or a few years in bottle to soften the edges and reveal its full complexity.

pairing_tags: roast beef, wild game, aged cheeses
insider_note: Nervi-Conterno Gattinara, from the historic Gattinara DOCG, showcases Nebbiolo (Spanna) on volcanic soils, yielding mineral-driven wines lighter than Barolo with exceptional aging potential due to firm tannins and vibrant acidity.

wine_name: "lydien no. 80" brut nature blanc de blancs (disg. 23)
insider_note: Expressive single-vineyard Blanc de Blancs from Le Chemin de Flavigny plot in Le Mesnil-sur-Oger; biodynamically farmed 100% Chardonnay with 1g/L dosage, base 2022+40% perpetual reserve; chalk-driven with openness, energy, salinity, and floral-citrus notes.

Single-parcel, organically farmed Meunier-driven Champagne vinified in barrel and finished extra brut; expect precise, saline, red-fruited tension rather than opulence—decant briefly from a wider glass to let the chalky, almost red-wine-like depth unfurl.

pairing_tags: Comté cheese, roasted chicken, mushroom risotto, coq au vin jaune
insider_note: Savagnin from Jura's Cellier Saint Benoit 'Chambines' is a traditional white style (ouillé), showcasing high acidity, citrus, floral, and mineral notes with nutty potential; not oxidative Vin Jaune.

pairing_tags: fruits de mer, poisson grillé, fromages affinés
insider_note: Issue de vignes centenaires sur sols argilo-silico-calcaires, élevée 24-36 mois en fûts, ce chenin offre profondeur, notes de fruits exotiques, miel et pierre mouillée, avec texture riche et saline persistante[3].

wine_name: "les grands teppes vieilles vignes" pinot noir
"le pre du col" ribbon ridge, willamette valley, oregon
insider_note: Pinot Noir; cranberry, earth, tea.

insider_note: High acid, low tannin, juicy berry.
Ethereal and light-footed with savory notes of mint, dried lemon peel, almond, and sage; aged 2 years in used wooden vats for textural finesse and aging potential like aged Riesling.
Iconic, ultra-traditional Sagrantino: massive tannin, dark fruit and earthy, savory complexity. Needs long air or years of cellaring; best with rich, slow-cooked meats to tame the structure.
Structured and balanced red wine profile.
Foradori Granato 2021, cool Teroldego grace.
Youthful Super Tuscan, bold primary fruit.
Savigny 2022: elegant reds, soft tannins.
Ethereal Saar trockenfrucht style; rapier acidity, green apple and slate.
Young Mosel Riesling, pure precision.

Low-pressure, zero-dosage Pinot Noir Champagne with incisive acidity and a saline, mineral finish; serve in a white-wine glass and give it a bit of air to let the pear, apple and pastry notes open up.

High-altitude Cannonau from granite soils gives this wine vibrant, almost ‘crunchy’ red fruit with notable acidity and moderate tannins; lean more toward food with some fat and herbs than heavy sauces to let the freshness and wild-strawberry, cranberry and herbal notes shine.[1][2][3][4][6][9]
Barrique-fermented Friulano from Ponca soils in Buttrio; yields are exceptionally low, no steel used, delivering minerality, almond finish, and saline vibrancy despite 'basic' status.

Classic Vosne-Romanée from Berthaut-Gerbet is typically a poised mix of power and finesse: medium+ body, silky but present tannins, and moderate, unobtrusive acidity, with a velvety, spicy, red-and-black-berry profile that shines with refined roast poultry or elegant game rather than heavy sauces.

pairing_tags: roast chicken, duck, veal, mushrooms, truffle dishes, mild soft cheeses
insider_note: Classic Chambolle-Musigny Pinot Noir is known for its floral violet bouquet, red raspberry and strawberry fruit, and especially its silky, lace-like texture with fine, smooth tannins and relatively moderate acidity, making Hudelot-Noëllat’s version an elegant, aromatically expressive Burgundy best enjoyed with refined but not overly powerful dishes.[2][3][7]

pairing_tags: apéritif, fruits de mer, Saint-Jacques, jambon ibérique
insider_note: 100% Chardonnay Grand Cru from Côte des Blancs, blend of 15 vintages since 1988 with solera reserve wines; features intense freshness, tension, mature richness, fine integrated bubbles, notes of ripe fruits, hazelnuts, brioche, and pure finish.

wine_name: "les peignottes" extra brut blanc de blancs
insider_note: 100% Chardonnay Grand Cru Extra Brut with floral nose, ripe white fruits, noble bitterness finish, and precise mineral tension from extended lees aging.

Among Huet’s three lieux-dits, Clos du Bourg sec is the most calcareous and often the most powerful: expect intense, laser-like acidity wrapped in a surprisingly dense, almost waxy texture and a long, saline, chalky finish that rewards 10–20 years of cellaring in top vintages.

Top single-vineyard Barbaresco from a traditional, low-intervention grower; expect taut nebbiolo structure, lifted acids, and floral red fruit that reward decanting now and cellaring for further complexity.

pairing_tags: ribeye, grilled steak, lamb, game, hard cheese, truffle dishes
insider_note: Modern Supertuscan in a Bordeaux mold: powerful yet balanced, with ripe dark fruit, graphite and balsamic notes, fresh acidity and polished but assertive tannins—decanting is strongly recommended, and top vintages reward 10+ years of cellaring.[1][2][3]

pairing_tags: ripe cherries, raspberries, plums, dark chocolate
insider_note: Beautiful silky Pinot Noir from old vines; great QPR with well-integrated tannins, juicy red fruit, and feminine, velvety style.

Saumur rouge with Cabernet Franc purity and savory finesse.

pairing_tags: roast chicken, duck breast, pork loin, mushroom dishes, mild hard cheeses, roast root vegetables
insider_note: Santenay Gravité is a blend of old-vine village and premier cru parcels (Les Hâtes, Gravières, Passetemps), giving a more complete and structured Pinot Noir than a typical village bottling while retaining Jean‑Marc Vincent’s hallmark precision, freshness, and finesse.[7]
Structured and balanced red wine profile.
Montalcino classic, vibrant and structured.
Elegant rosé with strawberry and chalk vibrancy.
Pure citrus, nervy Mesnil minerality.
NV BdN: Pinotto purity, red fruit focus.
Alpine crisp, pure quartz minerality.
2023 freshness with Vaillons perfume; very gastronomic.

pairing_tags: Charcuterie, Roast chicken, Mushroom dishes, Soft cheeses
insider_note: Blanc de Noirs with gentle grip; serious food white from Cabernet Franc.
Satellite: floral, high-toned Sancerre with polished mid-palate.
Sancerre Satellite, ripe poised balance.
VGW lean, high-toned acidity.
Laser-guided Oregon Chardonnay; struck match, citrus and precision.
2019 La Gioia: Ripe Chianti elegance.

Top-tier Franciacorta from Ca’ del Bosco, Annamaria Clementi is a long-lees-aged, Chardonnay/Pinot-based metodo classico with very high acidity, ultra-fine mousse, and a creamy yet tense profile; treat it like mature vintage Champagne, serve 10–12°C in a large white wine or tulip glass, and pair with refined seafood or truffle-driven dishes rather than heavy sauces.[1][2][3][5]

pairing_tags: earthy sausages, wild mushrooms, cheese, rich savory dishes
insider_note: Paolo Bea's Rosso di Veo is a lighter Sagrantino blend from Umbria, showcasing the grape's hallmark extreme tannins and full body with preserved acidity, ideal for decanting and aging to soften its robust structure.

pairing_tags: roasted red meats, game, aged cheeses
insider_note: Flagship Tuscan IGT blend (typically 45-50% Merlot, 40% Cabernet Sauvignon, 10-15% Petit Verdot) from organic grapes on galestro soils; full-bodied with supple, cashmere-like tannins, black fruit, chocolate, and spice notes; ages gracefully in French oak (best after 2028 for recent vintages).

A benchmark, classically styled Chianti Classico Riserva: bright sangiovese acidity and fine, integrated tannins give it the lift and grip to age gracefully while still showing juicy red and black berries, subtle spice and tobacco. Decant 1–2 hours to soften the structure and let the floral and mineral notes emerge; it shines with simply salted grilled beef or Tuscan-style roast meats.

Iconic Campanian Bordeaux-style blend (Cabernet Sauvignon, Aglianico, Merlot) with high but polished tannins, vibrant acidity, and deep black-fruit, tobacco and spice notes; decant generously in its first 10–15 years to soften structure and unlock the graphite, herb and mineral layers.
Classic high-acid, mineral Northern Piedmont Nebbiolo with finely etched tannins; give it a long decant or 5–10 years in bottle to let the florals and iron-tinged earthiness fully unfurl.
Structured and balanced red wine profile.

wine_name: Sauvignon Blanc, Sancerre, Clos Du Nozay

insider_note: Elegant, violet-scented, feminine.

2022 Maranges, ripe and approachable.
Generous 2022 Pommard; ripe and structured.
Anderson Valley cool; vibrant pinot focus.

pairing_tags: roast chicken, creamy cheeses, seafood risotto
insider_note: Domaine Jean-Marc Vincent's Auxey-Duresses Les Breterins is a white Burgundy Chardonnay from their small estate, noted for rich, layered fruit, intense terroir expression, and solid structure; aged in 10-15% new oak with lees stirring for texture and evolution in cellar.[1][5]
Structured and balanced red wine profile.
Etna Bianco with precision and breadth; citrus, anise, and lava‑rock minerality.
2022 Perrières: precise, mineral vibrancy.
Ripe 2022 Nuits; aromatic intensity shines.

Textbook Quintarelli white: a Garganega-led blend with vibrant, almost saline acidity and a subtly oily texture, giving you both refreshment and serious complexity—treat it more like a fine white Burgundy when pairing and serving (cool, not ice-cold, and in a good Burgundy stem).

Etichetta Bianca is a benchmark mountain Nebbiolo from Carema: pale garnet, highly aromatic (rose, herbs, stone), with bright, steely acidity and firm but refined tannins that age beautifully while staying delicate and savory.

pairing_tags: white meat, fish, aperitif, charcuterie, cheese
insider_note: This Brut Nature Blanc de Noirs likely delivers lively acidity, fine mousse, vinous character from Pinot Noir, and mineral freshness, with power and roundness typical of the style.

pairing_tags: fruits de mer, huîtres, tartare de thon, risotto alla vongole, shellfish, crab
insider_note: Blanc de Noirs 100% Pinot Noir de Côte des Bar (Kimméridgien), nord exposé, fermenté naturellement en fûts, long élevage sur lies, dégorgé 2023, vif et minéral avec salinité persistante.

pairing_tags: huîtres, fruits de mer, crustacés, tartare de thon, risotto aux coquillages, cuisine japonaise épurée
insider_note: Brut nature de Pinot Noir sur sols kimméridgiens de la Côte des Bar, Boréal joue plus la tension crayeuse et la salinité que la puissance noire d’un Blanc de Noirs classique : pensez citron, nectarine, pomme croquante et silex, avec une bulle très fine et une finale salivante taillée pour les fruits de mer et les textures iodées.[1][2][4][7][8]
100% Pinot Noir blanc de noirs from biodynamic Aube vines; complex with citrus, minerality, dried fruits, red fruits, fine persistent bubbles, saline structure, and lively energy[1][2][5]

wine_name: "les terres fine" extra brut blanc de blancs (disg. 23)
insider_note: Cuis 1er Cru Chardonnay from north-facing slopes with perpetual reserve since 1986; steely minerality balanced by richness, dosage 2g/L, 8 months on fine lees.

pairing_tags: oysters, shellfish, crab, scallops, sushi, tempura, soft cheeses, aperitif
insider_note: Extra Brut Champagne from Emmanuel Brochet’s Selected series shows vibrant, chalky acidity and ripe orchard fruit with a creamy yet precise texture, making it especially strong with delicate seafood and as a high-energy aperitif.[1][4][8]
Extra Brut blend of 56% Pinot Noir, 22% Meunier, 22% Chardonnay, dosed at 3g/L; precise, complex, and traditional style from Gaspard Brochet's single-vineyard focus in Ecueil and Sacy[1][3][5].

pairing_tags: oysters, scallops, sashimi, roast chicken, veal, truffled dishes, hard cheeses
insider_note: Les Couarres is one of Chartogne-Taillet’s most terroir-driven cuvées: a dense yet finely cut blanc de noirs with pronounced salinity and mineral tension, best with food and even better after 3–5 years of extra bottle age.

100% Pinot Meunier from 50-year-old vines in a single 1-hectare parcel in Chatillon-sur-Marne; very low yields, aged in old barrels, no malo-lactic fermentation, refined with persistent bubbles, wild herbs, ginger, honey, chalk, and racy acidity.
Chassagne-Montrachet whites from Bachelet-Monnot offer elegant minerality, citrus, white flowers, and balanced freshness with aging potential for hazelnut and honey notes.

pairing_tags: roast meats, veal, charcuterie, mild cheeses, white meats
insider_note: This Pinot Noir from the Hautes-Côtes de Beaune shows fresh red fruit aromas like cherry and raspberry, with balanced acidity and friendly tannins from clay-limestone soils at higher altitudes; expect round, spontaneous palate evolving to spice and undergrowth notes after 10-12 months in barrels.

Philippe Valette's 'Et Pourtant' Viré-Clessé is a Chardonnay from the Mâcon Viré-Clessé appellation, known for its lively freshness, minerality from calcareous/clay soils, and notes of citrus, white peach, floral aromas, and white flowers; expect a dry, round, well-balanced profile with vibrant acidity and subtle creaminess from lees aging.

wine_name: macvin du jura, sud revermont chardonnay

insider_note: Chenin Blanc de vieilles vignes biodynamiques sur schistes, minéral et tendu, gagne en texture après 5 ans; équilibre parfait acidité-rondeur avec fraîcheur et salinité.

Single-vineyard Chenin Blanc monopole from old vines (planted 1970s), biodynamically farmed, aged 2 years in oak; benefits from 5+ years for textural development, shows minerality, salinity, and power.

pairing_tags: white fish, roast chicken, rich shellfish, risotto, soft cheeses
insider_note: Old-vine, biodynamic Chenin from a tiny monopole; expect dense, mineral, slightly woody structure in youth that needs a few years in bottle to fully knit into its characteristic creamy, saline texture.

pairing_tags: roasted poultry, foie gras, aged cheeses
insider_note: Biodynamic Chenin Blanc from schist-quartz soils in Roche-aux-Moines; benefits from long decanting and aeration to reveal minerality, ripe fruit, and oxidative spice notes[1][2]

Natural, old-vine Viognier Condrieu with ripe apricot and nectarine aromas, moderate freshness and a rich, oily mouthfeel; serve slightly chilled and drink relatively young to enjoy its vivid stone-fruit and floral character.

From Mugneret-Gibourg, this village Bourgogne Rouge punches above its appellation with estate's signature purity, fine tannins, and aging potential of 5+ years; 2022 shows dark fruits, elegance, and 13% alcohol.

insider_note: Iconic biodynamic Teroldego from Elisabetta Foradori, Granato is the most structured, age-worthy wine in the range, showing vibrant acidity, firm yet refined tannins, and deep dark-fruit and mineral notes—treat it like a serious Northern Italian red and decant generously for best aromatic complexity.[2][4][5][7]

pairing_tags: roast meats, Mediterranean casseroles, aged cheese
insider_note: Elegant Sicilian red from steep Messina slopes, blending rare indigenous grapes like Nerello Mascalese and Nocera; aged 24 months in oak for silky tannins and persistence, often scoring 93-98 points.

Benchmark biodynamic Teroldego from Elisabetta Foradori: deep, mineral, and ageworthy, it drinks like a mountain cross between northern Rhône Syrah and Alto Piemonte Nebbiolo, with vibrant acidity and refined but definite structure that rewards a long decant or 5–10 years of cellaring.

pairing_tags: lamb, beef stew, game, ragù pasta, aged cheeses
insider_note: Classic structured Montepulciano d’Abruzzo Riserva: dark cherry and berry fruit, moderate freshness, and firm but polished tannins make it ideal for rich, slow-cooked meat dishes and hearty Abruzzese cuisine.

Paolo Bea Pipparello is a rare field blend from Umbria, often Sangiovese-dominant with Sagrantino influences, delivering bold, structured power from extended oak aging; expect intense red berries, spice, and impressive longevity.

2016 Conero: focused black cherry, iodine, and fine maritime tension.

2023 Guidalberto: bright cassis, bay, ready before Sassicaia.

Bize Bourgogne punches up: savory, mineral, and classically structured.

pairing_tags: rich pasta with meat ragù, braised beef, grilled lamb, aged hard cheeses, mushroom dishes, truffle-forward Piedmontese cuisine
insider_note: Barbera from Conterno’s Vigna/Cascina Francia vineyard is unusually deep and structured for the grape, with very high acidity but modest tannin, making it both a powerful red and an exceptionally food-flexible pairing for rich, savory dishes.

pairing_tags: rich game,dark chocolate,blue cheese,hard aged cheese,braised meats,roast lamb
insider_note: Dry passito Nebbiolo from the Alps: think Amarone meets Barolo, with concentrated cherry, plum and raisin notes, high alcohol, firm yet polished tannins and enough acidity to stay lively—decant generously to tame the warmth and unlock its spice-driven complexity.

pairing_tags: Beef, Lamb, Game, Charcuterie-Cheese, Pasta-Red, Pork
insider_note: Austere Northern Rhône-style Syrah with Tuscan accent; firm, structured tannins that soften with age; ripe, savory notes of black fruit, pepper, bacon fat, and leather[1][2]

pairing_tags: grilled meats, pasta, cured meats, Tuscan dishes
insider_note: Monterinaldi 'Vigneto Boscone' Chianti Classico, a premium single-vineyard expression, exemplifies Sangiovese-driven vibrancy with floral-cherry aromas, firm tannins, high acidity, and medium body typical of the region.

pairing_tags: grilled red meats, game, mature cheeses, pasta with red sauce
insider_note: Aglianico del Vulture from Cantine del Notaio offers full-bodied structure with firm tannins that soften to silky with age, mineral notes from volcanic soils, and excellent aging potential up to 20 years.

pairing_tags: roasted meats, wild game, aged cheeses
insider_note: Porcaria yields lush, robust Nerello Mascalese from old vines at 650m on Etna's volcanic slopes, known for spicy, mineral, smoky character with fresh red fruit and earthy finesse[2][5].

wine_name: Chenin Blanc, Savennieres, Les Vieux Clos
insider_note: Classic white wine profile; bright and food-friendly.
Structured and balanced red wine profile.

wine_name: Extra Brut Oiry Blanc de Blancs
insider_note: Extra Brut from Oiry (Côte des Blancs) showcases intense minerality and chalk-driven purity from Chardonnay on limestone soils, with lively citrus, white flowers, and exceptional aging potential.

pairing_tags: oysters,sushis,salmon carpaccio,smoked salmon canapés,red fruit tart
insider_note: Blended from 65% 2019 Grand Cru Chardonnay, 30% perpetual reserve Chardonnay, and 5% Pinot Noir vinified as still red wine; aged 3 years on lees for finesse and freshness[1][2][4][6].

pairing_tags: citrus-cured salmon, spicy chicken, grilled chicken, crustaceans, fatty fish, soft cheese
insider_note: Fresh and lively Chardonnay from Puligny-Montrachet with lemon, pear, and mineral notes; racy and elegant with vibrant entry and good persistence[1][2][7]

pairing_tags: truffle, hard cheese, game bird, mushroom, polenta, alpine
insider_note: A benchmark alpine Nebbiolo from terraced Carema vineyards: very high, racy acidity, fine but persistent tannins, and a pale, garnet, aromatic profile (rose, red fruit, stone, herbs). Etichetta Bianca is the more traditional, elegant and lightweight bottling—decant gently and serve closer to 16°C to keep its perfume and minerality at the forefront.

pairing_tags: roast beef, wild game, mushroom risotto, aged cheeses
insider_note: Produttori del Barbaresco's Muncagotta is a cooperative standout from the 2020 vintage, showcasing sour cherry, rose petals, tobacco, and wet stone with high tannins, high acid, full body, and a long finish—elegant yet ageworthy Nebbiolo[4]

pairing_tags: beef, lamb, roasted meats, pork, cured meats, aged cheeses
insider_note: Ronchi di Cialla revived Schioppettino from near-extinction using original vines from Cialla Valley, yielding structured, age-worthy wines with black fruit, spice, and Friuli terroir expression.

Single-vineyard Boscone shows the taut, fresh side of Radda Sangiovese, with a crunchy acid spine and well-integrated tannins that make it ideal for rich but not heavily sauced Tuscan dishes.[3][7][5]

100% Pinot Noir Blanc de Noirs Extra Brut from Françoise Martinot (Charles Dufour), base likely around 2024 (disg. 24); vinous with volume, chewiness, oxidative notes, fruit-driven minerality, and pastry elements.
Full-bodied 100% Chardonnay Blanc de Blancs from Beaunay with oak aging, zero dosage, and notes of stone fruit, pear, and saline finish; 94-point Wine Advocate score[1].
Elite Aligote from Bouzeron by Sylvain Pataille, known for high acidity, citrus notes, and subtle oak; green/flinty style from Cote Chalonnaise.

Benchmark off-dry Loire Chenin: ripe orchard and exotic fruit, honeyed nuance and strong saline-mineral drive, with enough residual sugar to feel tender but high acidity keeping it precise—serve a touch cooler than typical (10–11°C) if you want to emphasize tension over richness.
Traditionalist Cabernet Franc from old vines in Candes-Saint-Martin, lean and laser-focused with wild yeasts and vivid natural wine bite; 2002 vintage sang beautifully.
Zero sulfur natural Gringet from Savoie, biodynamic, lees-aged for richness; citrusy aromatics like yuzu, pear skin, wet stone with vibrant minerality[1][4][7]

Keller’s Alte Reben Réserve is a Chardonnay–Pinot Blanc blend from old vines in Rheinhessen, combining ripe stone and orchard fruit with pronounced minerality and lively but balanced acidity; it shows Keller’s hallmark sleek, polished texture and can age several years for more complexity.[1][3][4][6][7][8]
Burgundy-style oak-aged Xarel·lo with high ageing potential, guided by acidity harvest, showing chalky freshness and opulent structure[1][5]

2015 Barbacarlo, warm solar depth.
Youngest Quintarelli; bright, vinous, everyday-table red.
Structured Bolgheri, cool classic style.
Altesse with depth: ripe stone fruit over waxy, mineral-driven frame.
Grandes Jorasses, mineral intensity.

pairing_tags: sushi, charcuterie, grilled salmon, langoustine, red-berry desserts, aperitif
insider_note: Benchmark grower-style rosé Champagne: very high, tangy acidity and precise red-berry fruit wrapped in a creamy, fine bead. Versatile enough for sushi and seafood but also for charcuterie and lightly sweet red-fruit desserts; serve well-chilled to highlight its tension and minerality.

pairing_tags: red meat, braise, game, hard cheese, truffle, mushroom, tomato-based
insider_note: Classic high-altitude Nebbiolo from volcanic soils: bright red fruit, floral and mineral, with firm but refined tannins that reward decanting or mid-term cellaring.

pairing_tags: roast poultry, wild game, aged cheeses
insider_note: Exceptionally age-worthy Pinot Nero from Alto Adige's premier Barthenau Vigna S. Urbano site, evolving to super-fine tannins, tobacco, and dark berry notes with alpine freshness[1][2][5][8]

pairing_tags: grilled meats, traditional Sardinian dishes, aged cheeses
insider_note: Santadi Terre Brune exemplifies Carignano del Sulcis from ancient bush vines in Sulcis' sandy soils, delivering intense marasca cherry and dried fruit aromas with a structured, savory profile reflecting the rugged Mediterranean terroir.[10][2]

wine_name: Extra Brut L'Échappée Belle Blanc de Blancs
insider_note: 100% Chardonnay Blanc de Blancs from 1er Cru Côte des Blancs vineyards; extra brut (2g/L dosage), fine bubbles, aged 36+ months on lees; aromas of brioche, white flowers, green apple, peach; vibrant freshness with integrated acidity.

Very low dosage and long lees aging give Éphémère a racy, saline, high-tension profile with fine bubbles; treat it more like a serious white Burgundy in its pairing range than a simple aperitif Champagne.

wine_name: Blanc des Blancs Les Terres Fines
insider_note: Bone-dry Extra Brut Blanc de Blancs from Cuis 1er Cru Chardonnay, with steely minerality, racy acids, and richness from a perpetual reserve dating to 1986; dosage 2g/L, biodynamic farming.

pairing_tags: Tuscan cuisine, grilled lamb, bistecca alla fiorentina, aged pecorino, tomato-based pasta, porcini mushrooms
insider_note: A serious, Brunello-level Rosso di Montalcino with lively freshness, chalky yet polished tannins and sweet spice; benefits from a short decant despite its approachability.
Vin Jaune from Savagnin grapes aged 6+ years under flor yeast, yielding nutty, sherry-like flavors with exceptional aging potential.
Powerful yet sharply defined Smaragd Grüner from Kellerberg: expect high acidity, a concentrated but not heavy mid‑palate, and a long, dry, spicy–mineral finish that can age for well over a decade.
Field blend white from Bierzo with Godello and Palomino; austere aromatics of dried herbs, hay, lemon oil, and pear evolve to medium+ structure with salinity from schist soils.
Elegant Nebbiolo; floral and earthy.

As a Brut Nature Champagne with zero dosage (<3g/L sugar), it delivers pure terroir expression through sharp freshness, mineral tension, citrus, white flowers, and chalky notes, ideal for purists seeking unmasked vibrancy.

Complex white blend from high-altitude Etna vines (1,200m) with Carricante, Riesling, Gewurztraminer, Chenin Blanc, and Grecanico; naturally fermented in steel, aged on lees for spice, fatness, and aging potential; early picking preserves fresh white fruit aromas[1][2][3][4][5][6]
Biodynamic Vermentino from Corsica's Figari region, known for bright gold color, mineral and herbal notes with subtle fruit and lightly bitter finish[1][2][4][5]

Flavio Roddolo's Barbera d'Alba exemplifies the grape's signature high acidity and low tannins, offering vibrant cherry-plum fruit with plush texture; ages gracefully in bottle, balancing freshness and elegance over years.

Sun-soaked Juffer Sonnenuhr; lush yellow fruit, strong mineral drive.

pairing_tags: oysters, raw_bar, shellfish, caviar, sushi_sashimi, light_aperitif_bites, goat_cheese, triple_cream_cheese, chicken_in_cream_sauce
insider_note: Classic Grand Cru Côte des Blancs Chardonnay Champagne: high‑acid, mineral and chalk-driven with a creamy mousse and notes of citrus, green apple, brioche and wet stone; long considered an insider’s buy for serious Blanc de Blancs quality at a relatively modest price.

pairing_tags: seafood, white fish, risotto, light pasta
insider_note: Barrique-aged Ribolla Gialla blend from the exclusive Cialla cru in Friuli, emphasizing native varieties like Ribolla Gialla, Picolit, and Verduzzo on Eocene marl soils for elegant, age-worthy white wines.[1][2][6]

pairing_tags: roasts, braised meats, game, aged cheeses, spicy meats
insider_note: Arianna Occhipinti's Grotte Alte elevates Cerasuolo di Vittoria with its organic, terroir-driven expression of Nero d'Avola and Frappato, offering cherry depth, floral lift, and balanced vibrancy from sandy Sicilian soils.

High-tension, oak-vinified prestige Champagne with no malolactic fermentation, so expect very bright acidity wrapped in a rich, brioche-and-hazelnut profile; give it a large glass and 10–15 minutes in the glass for the full orchestra of aromas to unfold.

wine_name: Extra Brut 7 Crus Blanc de Blancs
pairing_tags: oysters, shellfish, ceviche, sushi, tempura, fresh goat cheese, triple-cream cheese, tartare, light poultry, apéritif
insider_note: Classic grower Blanc de Blancs from Agrapart: laser-cut Chardonnay acidity wrapped in a chalky, saline creaminess. Extra Brut dosage keeps it racy and dry, so serve slightly warmer than fridge-cold (around 9–10°C) to let the chalk, citrus and brioche notes open up, and avoid pairing with very spicy or heavy sauced dishes that can overwhelm its finesse.

Classic high-toned Sangiovese from a top traditional Montalcino estate: bright cherry and floral aromas, lively acidity, and fine-grained tannins make this more about energy and precision than power—treat it like a serious Burgundy and serve slightly cool in a large bowl to let the aromatics soar.

From historic biodynamic vines first planted by Cluny monks in 910, this naturally vinified red shows bright red fruit, peppery spice and lively acidity with very supple tannins, so serve it slightly chilled and avoid heavy oak-driven reds alongside it for best effect.

Classic old-vine Aglianico from high-altitude Taurasi with firm, ageworthy tannins and vibrant acidity; give it a long decant or pair with rich, slow-cooked meats to soften its structure and highlight the deep black fruit, tobacco, spice, and umami notes.
Grand Saint-Joseph Syrah from biodynamic granite terroir; ample, gourmand mouth with fine tannins enveloping like candy, black fruits, cedar, menthol, aging potential to 2035+.

insider_note: 100% Pinot Noir parcellaire de Landreville (Côte des Bar), élevé 11 mois en fûts de chêne, brut nature non dosé, tension fraîche et élégante du millésime 2021 marqué par gel et pluie.

Skin-contact Trebbiano Spoletino from Bea that drinks like a structured orange wine: high, mouthwatering acidity and a firmly tactile, mineral grip make it far more of a food wine than an aperitif, especially with earthy, umami-driven dishes.[1][2][3][8][9]

pairing_tags: oysters, crudo, white fish, shellfish, sushi, soft cheeses, aperitif
insider_note: A benchmark grower Extra Brut from Avize: 90% Chardonnay, 10% Pinot Noir, blending 7 Côte des Blancs villages for a linear, saline, mineral style with bright apple, lemon, stone fruit and a fine mousse—more racy and chalk-driven than rich or autolytic.[2][3][4][6]

Iconic 100% Merlot from Lazio showing dark concentrated fruit yet notable freshness; expect ripe plum, blackberry, vanilla and a long, elegant finish with polished tannins and modern, barrique-driven styling.
Full-bodied Aglianico del Vulture from volcanic soils; firm tannins soften to silky with age, mineral-driven structure from Monte Vulture.

pairing_tags: roasted red meats, game, mature cheeses
insider_note: Powerful Sardinian blend dominated by Cannonau (Grenache), aged in French oak barriques for 18-24 months; robust with integrated tannins, excellent aging potential of 5-8+ years, decant young vintages to soften initial density.

High-altitude Nerello Mascalese from Etna’s Guardiola cru tends to show bright acidity, fine but present tannins, and a medium body with red cherry, cranberry, blood orange and distinct volcanic minerality—treat it more like an alpine Pinot Noir than a rich Southern Italian red.[2][3][4]

Classic, quietly powerful Barbaresco: bright acidity and firm but polished tannins framed by dark fruit, sweet spice and underbrush; give it airtime or a few more years in bottle and pair with richer, savory dishes to let the elegance shine.[1][2][3][6]

pairing_tags: grilled_white_meats, light_pork, charcuterie, caponata, tomato_pasta, medium_cheese
insider_note: Contrada PT Frappato from Occhipinti is all about bright, saline red fruit—think sour cherry and pomegranate—with high, mouthwatering acidity and very gentle tannins, so treat it almost like a serious cru Beaujolais: serve slightly chilled and avoid heavy sauces to let its delicacy and savory, blood-orange edge shine.[1][3][5][7]
Pinot Noir bourguignon juteux et puissant, avec acidité vive/explosive, fruits rouges/noirs, minéralité graphite et tanins soyeux.

wine_name: "la crayère" extra brut blanc de blancs
insider_note: 100% Chardonnay from old vines (1962-1963) on argilo-calcaire soil in Bisseuil Premier Cru; extra brut nature (0g/L), vinified in small oak fûts with 9 months lees aging; refined white fruits, woody, mineral, lively tension, saline finish.

insider_note: Juicy, crunchy Côte de Beaune Pinot Noir with ripe raspberry fruit and low acidity; elegant and refined, best from 2026-2035.

insider_note: 70% Frappato / 30% Nero d'Avola blend, unfiltered, biodynamic, high-toned with bright cherry-strawberry fruit, floral aromas, savory earthiness; lively entry-level Sicilian red that's fun yet terroir-driven.
Warm, ripe; impeccable fruit quality.

pairing_tags: Foie Gras, Blue Cheese, Fruit Dessert
insider_note: Young d’Yquem: marmalade, saffron, honeyed depth, electric spine.
Racines Grande Réserve: California Chardonnay with clear Côte de Beaune inspiration.
Benchmarked NV Champagne: delicately toasty, crowd‑pleasing, reliable.
Barbaresco grace, softer Nebbiolo charm.
Solar vintage, vibrant Sangiovese.
NV chalky Champagne is the benchmark match.
High-toned Trebbiano with Tuscan stones, citrus pith and herbs.
Vibrant Aligote structure.
PYCM 2024: ultra‑tense, high‑wire Burgundy, all stones and citrus.
Electric acidity, lean Burgundy rosé.
Langhe Nebbiolo, balanced power.
La Morra finesse; vibrant cool acidity.

pairing_tags: Roast chicken, Pork loin, Mushroom dishes
insider_note: Burgundy meets Jura: taut red fruit, fine tannins, and saline snap.
2019 ripe, harmonious Sangiovese.
More solar than 2018; Brunello with extra mid-palate flesh and gloss.
Auslese sweetness with Keller’s rapier acidity; featherweight yet intense.

Bollinger Special Cuvée is one of Champagne’s benchmark non-vintage bottlings: Pinot Noir–driven, generously autolytic (brioche, nuts, pastry) yet kept lively by crisp, mouthwatering acidity, making it versatile enough to pour both as an aperitif and alongside roasted poultry or richer, sauce-based dishes.[1][3][4][5][7]

pairing_tags: medium-structured dishes, first courses, cheeses, cold cuts, white meats, fish, lamb kabobs
insider_note: Benchmark orange wine from 120+ year-old Trebbiano Spoletino vines wrapped around oak trees, fermented on skins for weeks with indigenous yeasts, aged 2+ years on lees in steel; amber hue, powerful tannins balanced by vibrant freshness, excellent aging potential with hydrocarbon evolution.
Sfursat from dried Nebbiolo grapes, aged 18-20 months in oak; full-bodied with jam, nuts, and warm, harmonic profile ideal for long aging.

pairing_tags: grilled meats, pasta with tomato sauce, aged cheeses
insider_note: Elegant Rosso di Montalcino from Sangiovese grapes, featuring perfumed floral and red fruit aromas with a smooth, finely knit palate and saline freshness[1][3][6]
Vibrant yet silky tannins with a lengthy finish of freshness; excellent aging potential from Aglianico on calcareous clay soils.[1][2]

pairing_tags: charcuterie, oysters, sashimi, fried chicken, soft cheeses, vegetable tempura
insider_note: Brut Nature and Grand Cru fruit make this a vibrant, high-acid Champagne with no dosage; expect a tense, saline, citrus-and-red-fruited profile that opens into creamier texture with air, so give it time in the glass rather than serving too cold.

pairing_tags: smoked fish, monkfish, rich risotto, roast poultry, game terrine, soft bloomy cheeses
insider_note: Serious Pinot Noir grower-Champagne: more like a mineral, vinous white Burgundy with fine mousse than a simple aperitif bubbly, so serve in a white-wine glass and pair with food rather than as a casual pre-dinner pop.

Complex cuvée of 60-70% Pinot Bianco, 25-30% Chardonnay, 5-10% Sauvignon Blanc from quartz-rich Alto Adige soils; partial malolactic and 12-month lees aging in large oak yield creamy minerality and >10-year potential; 2021 vintage shows vibrant tension per 97pt James Suckling[3].

Ronchi di Cialla Cialla Bianco is a refined white blend from the Cru Cialla subzone in Friuli, featuring native grapes like Ribolla Gialla, Picolit, and Verduzzo; aged in French oak barriques since 1977 for natural stabilization, yielding fresh, elegant wines with exceptional aging potential from old vines on eocene marl soils.[1][2][6]
Pure, mineral-driven Aligoté with indigenous yeast fermentation and oak aging, showing verticality and a sharp finish from a top Meursault producer.

pairing_tags: roasted meats, aged cheeses, earthy dishes
insider_note: Rinaldi's Freisa from Ravera cru offers rustic charm with funky edges, balancing ripe fruit and firm structure; macerated 2-3 weeks, aged in old botti with minimal SO2[1][2]

pairing_tags: steak, lamb, braised_beef, game, aged_cheese, rich_stews
insider_note: Ultra-traditional, long-aged 100% Cabernet Sauvignon from Monforte d’Alba, Bricco Appiani shows brooding dark fruit, Piemonte earth, herbs and a distinctly bitter, Italianate finish with serious tannic grip—decant for hours or give it many years in bottle for maximum complexity.[1]

Traditional, characterful Barbera from a benchmark Barolo estate: bright, driving acidity and dark berry fruit make it superb at the table, but it shows best with a bit of air and hearty, savory dishes.

pairing_tags: grilled red meats, roasted meats, meat sauces
insider_note: Old-vine Pinot Nero from 1967-planted vineyard in Oltrepò Pavese with clay-calcareous soils; tight, savory profile of clove, bark, dark cherry, and burnt orange; medium-bodied with juicy, soft tannins.[1][5][7]

pairing_tags: pizza, roasted meats, game birds, hard cheeses, tomato-based pasta, grilled vegetables
insider_note: Primofiore is Quintarelli’s so‑called “baby” red: a Corvina/Corvinone–Cabernet blend with bright violet and cherry aromas, notable freshness, and gritty yet polished tannins, making it unusually food‑versatile for a prestige Veneto producer.[1][2][6]

pairing_tags: beef, lamb, game, charcuterie, hard_cheese, rich_pasta_with_red_sauce, grilled_meats, barbecue
insider_note: Modern Tuscan Syrah with smoky black fruit, bacon fat and spice; give it air or a few extra years in bottle to let the firm, velvety tannins knit and the savory notes blossom.
Leanest and most delicate of the top cuvées, fresh and elegant with natural wine energy, bold and structured Malbec from Cahors.
Blanc de blancs Extra Brut from Chardonnay in Coteaux Vitryats, noted for freshness, aromatic finesse, and complexity; natural vinification with indigenous yeasts, no added sulfites[6][9]

Pouilly-Fuissé Chardonnay from Domaine de la Soufrandière 'En Chatenay - Zen' reflects the appellation's mineral-driven profile with subtle oak for texture; expect citrus, peach, and honey notes from limestone soils, smoother than unoaked Chablis.

pairing_tags: veal in creamy sauces, trout almondine, oysters, chicken liver pâté, avocado, smoked salmon, crab, lobster, creamy chicken curries, goats’ cheese tarts
insider_note: Full-bodied natural Chardonnay from old vines, oak-aged without preservatives; decant extensively to unlock layers of ripe citrus, orchard fruits, hazelnut, and saline minerality.

Chenin Blanc from Loire Valley, fermented in oak and acacia barriques with minimal intervention; bright high acidity, lean to rich fruit profile, aromatic with white fruits, florals, dried fruits, and hazelnut notes.

wine_name: "agostado" sanlúcar de barrameda perruno + uva rey
insider_note: Oxidative white from Ramiro Ibáñez blending nearly extinct Perruno and Uva Rey, showing old-school Jerez character: dry, salty, with confit fruit, baked apple and straw notes, great for sherry geeks who want palo cortado structure without fortification.
Cuvée emblématique honorant l'origine monastique de 910, assemblage naturel de pinot noir et gamay biodynamique, pureté remarquable et finale minérale.

Classic Nebbiolo from Treiso and Barbaresco vineyards: high-toned acidity, firm but polished tannins and a medium-plus body make this ideal to decant for 1–2 hours and serve slightly below room temperature with rich, protein-heavy dishes.[1][3][5][6][8]
Lonardo's Vigne d'Alto Taurasi from old vines showcases Aglianico's firm tannins and lively acidity, with dark fruit and volcanic minerality; age-worthy southern Italian powerhouse.

pairing_tags: freshwater fish, vegetable soups, light seafood
insider_note: Foradori's Fontanasanta Nosiola from Trentino's Dolomiti IGT stands out with pale lemon hue, lively grapefruit-elderberry aromas, crisp acidity, savory mouthfeel, minerality, and subtle almond finish; skin-contact maceration adds texture while preserving the grape's indigenous hazelnut nuance[1].

pairing_tags: bistecca, brasato, cinghiale, selvaggina, formaggi stagionati, ragù di manzo, agnello arrosto
insider_note: Second wine of Ornellaia dominated by Merlot, Le Serre Nuove typically shows ripe dark berries, cedar and balsamic herbs with **medium+ acidity, polished but firm tannins and full body**, drinking well young but gaining complexity over 8–12 years.[1][2][6][7]

pairing_tags: grilled meats, pasta with tomato sauce, aged cheeses
insider_note: Guidalberto 2023 blends 55% Cabernet Sauvignon and 45% Merlot, aged 15 months in French/American barriques; positioned as independent from Sassicaia, showcasing Bolgheri terroir with lively tannins and juicy freshness.[1][2]

Pietracupa Taurasi, made from 100% Aglianico in Campania's Taurasi DOCG, ages in oak for up to 3 years, delivering firm/solid tannins, vibrant acidity, full-bodied refinement, and notes of dark fruits, earth, spice, and minerals.

Light, harmonious NV Champagne blending Pinot Noir (28-30%), Chardonnay (29%), and Meunier (43%) from multiple vintages; features fine bubbles, fresh fruit aromas, precise freshness, and minerality from 50-month lees aging.

Benchmark Dolcetto d’Alba from a top Barolo estate: expect vibrant black cherry and plum fruit, low-ish acidity and moderate, gentle tannins in a medium body—perfect as the winemaker’s own everyday Langhe red and best enjoyed young, slightly chilled, with simple Piedmontese-style fare.

pairing_tags: truffle, game birds, mushroom risotto, aged cheeses, osso buco
insider_note: High-altitude Nebbiolo from volcanic, iron-rich soils gives Le Pianelle Bramaterra its hallmark tension: very bright acidity, refined but firm tannins, and perfumed red fruit and floral notes that reward a long decant or 5–10 years of cellaring.[1][2][3][8]
Lean and ethereal Nebbiolo from Serraboella's warmest slope in Neive, offering bright berry fruit, savory licorice and iris notes, with racy finesse and good tannins that age well.

pairing_tags: red meat, roast beef, lamb, game, semi-hard cheese, tomato-based pasta, herb-roasted dishes
insider_note: Guidalberto is a Cabernet Sauvignon–Merlot Super Tuscan that drinks with Bordeaux-like freshness: medium body, high but well-integrated acidity, and polished tannins, so it shines with savory, salty or fatty dishes and can feel quite zesty in younger vintages.[1][2][3][4]

pairing_tags: grilled meats, pasta with tomato sauce, aged cheeses
insider_note: High-altitude Radda Sangiovese offering fresh acidity, cherry fruit, and aging potential up to 10 years; spontaneous fermentation in concrete tanks enhances balance.

Siro Pacenti Pelagrilli is a modern-style Brunello: full-bodied and concentrated with firm but refined tannins, noticeable barrique influence, and vibrant acidity that will reward at least 5–8 years of cellaring for the oak and structure to fully harmonize.[1][2][6][8]

wine_name: autour de jonquières ∙ terrasses du larzac
insider_note: Elegant power from high-altitude Larzac terraces; Carignan-Syrah-Mourvèdre blend aged 24 months in barrels/tuns; profound terroir expression with great cellaring potential.

pairing_tags: duck, roast chicken, charcuterie, mushroom dishes, soft cheeses
insider_note: Classic Sylvain Pataille Marsannay Pinot Noir: fresh red-fruit driven, vibrant acidity and very fine, polished tannins, drinking well young but with a few years’ cellaring potential.[3][4][5][6][8]

wine_name: "les margues" priorat garnacha blanca + garnacha gris
insider_note: Blend from Priorat's rugged terroir, expect perfumed stone fruits, saline minerality, and herbal freshness from old-vine Garnacha Blanca and Gris.

insider_note: Iconic natural Tavel that drinks more like a chillable, carbonic Grenache-based light red than classic rosé: vibrant red fruits, floral notes and spice, with fresh acidity and very soft, silky tannins—serve just cool (not icy) to show its depth.[1][2][3]

insider_note: Dogliani DOCG Dolcetto offers lively freshness in youth with cherry-violet aromas and balanced tannins; Chionetti's Briccolero from high Langhe slopes emphasizes fruity vivacity and age-worthiness up to 8 years.

pairing_tags: rich red meats, duck, beef, lamb, venison, game, roasted meats, aged cheeses
insider_note: Light yet robust single-vineyard Teroldego from sandy alluvial soils in Trentino, biodynamically farmed and aged 8-12 months in clay amphorae for freshness, minerality, and fine dry tannins.

wine_name: "7 crus" extra brut blanc de blancs (disg. 25)
pairing_tags: apéritif, saumon cru, langoustines, tartare de saumon, papillote de loup aux agrumes
insider_note: Extra Brut Blanc de Blancs from 7 Crus (4 Grands Crus, 3 Premiers Crus), 90% Chardonnay + 10% Pinot Noir, low dosage (5g/L), aged 3+ years on lees, fresh tension with fine bubbles, complex nose of apple, almond, hazelnut, spices; palate shows fruits, white flowers, honey, minerality; Robert Parker 90/100.
Pinot Meunier still reds like this Chamery Rouge offer juicy red fruits and bright acidity, rarer than its Champagne blending role; seek old-vine examples for added complexity.
Richly textured Altesse from white marl slopes, with apricot, citrus, and saline freshness; biodynamically farmed, lees-aged in concrete ovoids for purity and minerality.[1][2][3][5]

pairing_tags: cauliflower cheese, honey-roasted ham, cheese fondue
insider_note: From schistose soils in Savoie, this Gringet undergoes whole bunch carbonic maceration with 15-day skin contact, yielding a fruity style where vibrant acidity dominates over subtle fruit notes.[3]

pairing_tags: seafood, shellfish, light salads, goat cheese
insider_note: Profoundly mineral Silvaner from Franken, biodynamically farmed on sandstone/limestone by Sylvaner specialist Stefan Vetter; taut, crisp, and terroir-driven with smoky, herbal, peppery notes[1][2][3][4][5]

Benchmark Pigato from 50-70+ year old vines on red clay soils in Arroscia Valley, offering balsamic richness, minerality, and elegant freshness[1][2][3][8][9]
